Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Intersectionality of Non-normative Identities in the Cultures of Engineering (InIce)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is motivated by the need to increase and diversify the engineering workforce, which will help to increase economic growth and prosperity in the United States. The ultimate goal of this project is to understand more effectively the ways in which students can become interested in pursuing engineering majors in college and how to help them persist through to the end of an engineering degree, with particular attention on those students who may have different views of the role of engineering. This will be accomplished by a large quantitative assessment followed by a longitudinal study of students who are identified as holding various normative or non-normative attitudinal profiles,
with a focus on understanding students' feelings of belongingness in engineering and their developing engineering identities. The outcomes of this work will result in practical ways to increase diversity in engineering programs through research-based recruitment and teaching strategies focused on student identities within engineering. Specific course materials will be developed to target graduate students entering academia (who will be teaching future engineering students) to help begin to foster a more welcoming culture in engineering.

The theoretical framing of this work is an intersectional approach towards "normativity" in engineering culture. Methodologically, this project will utilize modern statistical techniques to identify clusters of students through their attitudinal data, without the prior imposition of categorizations of students (e.g. gender, race, ethnicity) in order to understand how engineering students' attitudes group into various "normative" and "non-normative" profiles. Following this, we will conduct a longitudinal study of a selection of students from the empirically-identified attitudinal profiles to understand how these students navigate their engineering experiences and develop their identities in their chosen majors. The intellectual merit of this work is an improved understanding of the ways in which different students develop their engineering identities, navigate their engineering communities, and enculturate into their chosen disciplines as well as in the development of practical ways to help students be successful in engineering. This extends previous findings that dissatisfaction and lack of community within engineering are causes for students not choosing or leaving engineering studies. Addressing the core issue of student perceptions of not fitting into engineering can begin to staunch the exodus of talented individuals from engineering. The results of this research will then be incorporated into the development of workshops (for current graduate students and faculty) and widely available graduate
courses designed around diversity in engineering. The broader impact of this work will be to promote an empirically-validated understanding of how to retain a more diverse body of engineering majors including pragmatic solutions for educators and administrators, both at the researchers' institutions and in the wider engineering community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied how students who hold non-normative identities position themselves, grow during their education, and navigate the cultures of engineering they experience in college. We aimed to investigate ways of including diversity in the engineering community so that students with non-normative identities can feel like they belong in engineering and become more active and life-long participants in engineering disciplines. Our specific goals were to 1) Identify the attitudinal profiles of normative and non-normative students in engineering using quantitative methods, and 2) Understand students? normative and non-normative identities through in-depth case studies of college students that we identified through the quantitative methods in goal 1. We used robust research methods to explore differences between students with normative and non-normative identities in engineering.

An important part of this project is that we did not pre-define ?normative? and ?non-normative?; they are not based on demographic indicators like gender or race, which is the traditional approach to characterizing majority and minority students. Instead, we developed and adapted a cutting-edge statistical technique, Topological Data Analysis (TDA), which has not previously been used in education research. We used TDA to map and identify groups without imposing preconceived notions about how the attitudes of students may group together (nor how they may distinguish between demographic groups). This approach allows the underlying structure of the data to emerge rather than imposing pre-defined definitions of ?normative? attitudes or identities. After we characterized these attitudinal groups using TDA, our next goal was to understand how students belonging to normative and non-normative attitudinal profiles navigated their engineering experiences and defined their educational pathways through several interviews conducted with a select group of students over three years. We analyzed the interviews based on research related to students? identity and motivation, and looked for new insights into how students feel a sense of belongingness in engineering.

One of the outcomes of this study was to demonstrate how TDA can be applied in education research as a method for clustering data that doesn?t rely on pre-defined assumptions about the data or on pre-defined specifications of how the data should be distributed or clustered. Using this approach, our results reflect the complex nature of students? responses to questions about their identity, motivation, beliefs and attitudes towards engineering. TDA is particularly appropriate for this type of data because student attitudinal profiles (especially those profiles that many students hold in common) are not well understood and could be studied only at a surface level with analytic methods used in the past. 

Another important outcome of this work is that our methods allow us to describe student diversity from the perspective of each participant rather than using demographic indicators that are socially constructed from the perspective of others. Using student perspectives without the limitations of traditional demographics measures allowed for well-founded student identities that put students into ?bins? that may not represent the variety of their experiences and attitudes. This accurate reflection of diversity provides novel insight into the experiences of students who might otherwise be ignored or unjustifiably lumped in with other students with similar demographic indicators and how residing at the intersection of multiple measures of diversity influences students? experiences in engineering culture.

Our findings from the longitudinal interviews with engineering students allow us to give voice to their lived experiences. The knowledge gained from our analysis shows how underlying attitudes and beliefs may shape students? experiences and feelings of belongingness within engineering.
Students across both Normative and Near-Normative groups described a culture in engineering that might label itself as open to anyone, but is in fact exclusive to those who do not conform to certain expectations. Students? expectations include the idea that you must be ?gritty? (persistent at working towards goals and consistently interested and passionate about engineering) to succeed. The implications of these narratives are that although the doors to engineering are open to anyone passing by, if students don?t possess certain traits the welcoming atmosphere shifts, leaving students feeling out of place. Students? responses reflect a culture in engineering in which power is held by those with skill or ability. This focus on skills can result in turning a blind eye to structural barriers that exist for diverse students. Students may create in and out groups based on visible demographic characteristics, like race and gender, but also based on persistence towards goals and interest.

One aspect of the student experience that distinguished Normative from Near-Normative groups was that Normative students were encouraged but not pushed into engineering, and were supported in making their own decisions. Near-Normative students felt pushed into engineering, with others strongly influencing their choices.

We believe that this research will significantly inform engineering culture to be more aware of and inclusive of the different types of student diversity than are currently present in engineering.
